title: Local existence and uniqueness for a semi-linear accretive wave equation

title_detail.value: Local existence and uniqueness for a semi-linear accretive wave equation

summary:
We prove local existence and uniqueness of the solution $(u,u_t)\in
C^0([0,T];H^1\times L^2(\mathbb{R}^N))$ of the semilinear wave equation
$u_{tt}-\Delta u=u_t|u_t|^{p-1}$.

summary_detail.value:
We prove local existence and uniqueness of the solution $(u,u_t)\in
C^0([0,T];H^1\times L^2(\mathbb{R}^N))$ of the semilinear wave equation
$u_{tt}-\Delta u=u_t|u_t|^{p-1}$.

author: M. Jazar
fulltext:
Local existence and uniqueness for a
semi-linear accretive wave equation

arXiv:0901.4247v2 [math-ph] 17 Jun 2010

H. Faour∗, A. Z. Fino1 and M. Jazar1

November 9, 2018

Abstract

We study local existence and uniqueness in the phase space H μ × H μ−1 (RN ) of the
solution of the semilinear wave equation utt − ∆u = ut |ut |p−1 for p > 1.

Keywords: Wave equations; Strichartz estimates.

1

Introduction and main results

A very rich literature has been done on the semi-linear wave equation
utt − ∆u = aut |ut |p−1 + bu|u|q−1
with a, b, p and q are real numbers, p, q ≥ 1. When a ≤ 0 and b = 0 then
the damping term aut |ut |p−1 ensures global existence in time for arbitrary
data (see, for instance, Harraux and Zuazua [8] and Kopackova [10]). When
a ≤ 0, b > 0 and p > q or when a ≤ 0, b > 0 and p = 1 then one can cite,
for instance, Georgiev and Todorova [5] and Messaoudi [12], that show the
existence of global solutions under negative energy condition.
The first to consider the case a > 0 was Haraux [7] (with b = 0 on
bounded domain), who construct blowing up solutions for arbitrary small
initial data. See also Jazar and Kiwan [?] and the references therein for the
same equation on bounded domain.
∗

Cermics, Paris-Est-ENPC, ParisTech, 6 et 8 avenue Blaise Pascal, Cité
Descartes Champs-sur-Marne, 77455 Marne-la-Vallée Cedex 2, France.
E-mail:
faourh@cermics.enpc.fr.
1
A. Z. Fino and M. Jazar, LaMA-Liban, AZM Research Center, Lebanese University,
P.O. Box 37, Tripoli Lebanon. E-mails: afino@ul.edu.lb, mjazar@ul.edu.lb.
The first is supported by the project ANR MICA (2006-2010).
The second author is supported by a grant from the Lebanese National Research Council.
The third authors is supported by a grant from the Lebanese University.

1

 In this paper we consider the case a = 1 and b = 0, i.e. the semi-linear
accretive wave equation

p−1
x ∈ RN , t > 0,
 utt − ∆u = ut |ut |
(1)

u(0, x) = u0 (x), ut (0, x) = u1 (x) x ∈ RN .

To our knowledge, no local existence result was done for this equation. The
phase space to consider here is Y μ := H μ × H μ−1 (RN ), and we are looking
to find conditions on the nonlinearity p and the order μ so that we have
local existence. Due to our method, based on the use of Strichartz estimates
(Proposition 3) and bounds on a power of a function in a Sobolev space
khp kH s by the norm of the initial function khkH r , we need that p or μ to be
integer. This is done in the following two theorems
Theorem 1 (Case p integer)
Let p ∈ N\{0, 1} and μ ∈ R ∩ [1, ∞) such that

2

(2)

For (u0 , v0 ) ∈ Y μ , there exists a maximal time Tmax > 0 and a unique
solution (u, ut ) ∈ C 0 ([0, Tmax ); Y μ ) of problem (1). Moreover, if Tmax < ∞,
we have ku(t)kH μ + kut (t)kH μ−1 → ∞ as t → Tmax .
One can compare to the case a = 0 and b = 1, the restriction on p is the
same by taking μ = 2, see for instance [11, 14]).
In the previous theorem, p is integer. In the following theorem this is
no longer the case. However, the dimension must be less than 3 or equal.
This is due to Proposition 4 in which, we obtain L∞ -estimates on the wave
kernel. In what follows denote by Y 2,∞ := W 2,∞ × W 1,∞ (RN ).
Theorem 2 (Case p real)
Let 1 ≤ N ≤ 3, μ ∈ (1, 2) ∩ N∗ and p ∈ (1, ∞) ∩ [μ − 1, ∞). Then for
all (u0 , v0 ) ∈ Y μ ∩ Y 2,∞ there exists T > 0 and a unique solution (u, ut ) ∈
C 0 ([0, T ]; (L∞ ∩ H μ ) × L∞ ∩ H μ−1 (RN )) of (1).

2

Preliminary notations and results

In this section we use the notations used by [6]. For x ∈ X a normed
vector space we denote by kx; Xk the norm of x, and for (x, y) ∈ X × Y
then, naturally, k(x, y); X × Y k = kx; Xk + ky; Y k. Finally, for q ∈ [1, +∞)

The initial data U0 will be taken in the phase space Y μ for μ ∈ R where
H μ is the homogeneous Sobolev space (See [16]). We will use the following
"simplified version" of the generalized Strichartz inequality [15]:
Proposition 3 (Proposition 3.1 of [6]) Let ρ1 , ρ2 , μ ∈ R and q1 , q2 ≥ 2 and
let the following condition be satisfied
ρ1 − 1/q1 = μ = 1 − (ρ2 − 1/q2 ).
Then
1. kH(*)U0 ; Lq1 (R, Y ρ1 )k ≤ CkU0 ; Y μ k.

k(ω(*), ωt (*)); Lq1 (I, Y ρ1 )k ≤ Ckf ; Lq2 (I, H −ρ2 )k.
The constants C are independent of the interval I.

 For the proof of Theorem 2 we need the following proposition
Proposition 4 ([9, Lemma 3.4] and [13])
Let 1 ≤ N ≤ 3, f ∈ W 1,∞ (RN ) and g ∈ L∞ (RN ). Then, we have
kK̇(t)f ; L∞ (RN )k ≤ max(1, t)kf ; W 1,∞ (RN )k,

We will need also to deal with the Sobolev norm of a power of a function.
The following is a direct consequence of [2]:
Proposition 5 Let p ∈ N\{0, 1}, s > −N/2, s 6= N/2 and ν(s, p) :=
sup{0, (N/2−s)(p−1)/p}. Then, for a nonnegative function f ∈ H s+ν(s,p) (RN ),
f p ∈ H s (RN ) and there exists a positive constant C such that
kf p ; H s (RN )k ≤ Ckf ; H s+ν(s,p)(RN )kp .
Next, we give the Gagliardo-Nirenberg inequality which is a direct consequence of [3, Theorem 1.3.4] (see also [4, Theorem 9.3]).

Proof of theorems 1 and 2

Proof of Theorem 1. Without loss of generality, we may assume that
the initial data (u0 , v0 ) is of compact support. By finite speed of propagation, the solution (u, ut ) is also of compact support. This allows us to use
5

 Proposition 3 on bounded intervals [0, T ] with usual Sobolev spaces instead
of homogeneous Sobolev spaces (since for compactly supported distributions
the norms are equivalent, see [16]).
Now, we write (1) as

In order to use Fixed Point Theorem, let us introduce the following
metric space
X := {φ = (φ1 , φ2 ) ∈ Lq (0, T ; Y ρ ) s.t. kφ − HU0 ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k ≤ λ}
where T and λ are positive constants and ρ and q satisfy (6). These constants
will be fixed later.
For φ, ψ ∈ X denote by
kφ; Xk := kφ − HU0 ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k
(HU0 denotes the function t 7→ H(t)U0 ) and the natural induced distance
d(φ, ψ) := kφ − ψ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k.
Finally define the map Φ on X by Φ(U )(t) := H(t)U0 + L(U )(t).
First step: X is invariant under Φ. Let U ∈ X, by proposition 3 we have
kΦ(U ); Xk ≤ kL(U ); Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k ≤ Ckv p ; Lq2 (0, T ; H −ρ2 )k
for all (q2 , ρ2 ) satisfying (6). Take q2 := +∞, hence ρ2 := 1 − μ. Then
kΦ(U ); Xk ≤ Ckv p ; L1 (0, T ; H μ−1 )k.
By proposition 5
kv p ; H μ−1 k ≤ Ckv; H μ−1+ν(μ−1,p) kp ,

By choosing ρ = μ + ν(μ − 1, p) and q = p/(1 − ε), and using proposition 3,
inequality (10) gives

We see that, in both cases one has

with ρ and q satisfying (6). Thus we have
kΦ(U ); Xk ≤ CT ε kU ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )kp ≤ CT ε [kU ; Xk + kHU0 ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k]p ,
and, as ρ and q satisfy (6), by proposition 3 we have
kΦ(U ); Xk ≤ CT ε [kU ; Xk + kU0 ; Y μ k]p .
Therefore, X is invariant by Φ if T and λ are such that
CT ε (λ + kU0 ; Y μ k)p ≤ λ.

(13)

Second step: Φ is a contraction on X.
This is mainly the same ideas. Let U, V ∈ X. Then
d(Φ(U ), Φ(V )) = kL(U )−L(V ); Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )k ≤ CkU2p −V2p ; Lq2 (0, T ; H −ρ2 )k
for ρ2 and q2 satisfying (6). Take q2 := +∞, we get ρ2 := 1 − μ and then
d(Φ(U ), Φ(V )) ≤ CkU2p − V2p ; L1 (0, T ; H μ−1 )k.
Now, we write U2p − V2p = (U2 − V2 )P (U2 , V2 ) where P is a homogeneous
polynomial of degree p − 1. Using proposition 5 and the convexity of the
exponential function to obtain
d(Φ(U ), Φ(V )) ≤ CkU2 − V2 ; Lp (0, T ; H μ−1+ν(μ−1,p) )k

 By the same analysis, and a similar calculation as in the first step, we get
d(Φ(U ), Φ(V )) ≤ Cd(U, V )T ε [λ + kU0 ; Y μ k]p−1 .
Finally, Φ is a contraction on X if λ and T satisfy
CT ε [λ + kU0 ; Y μ k]p−1 < 1.

(14)

By choosing λ and T satisfying (13) and (14), Fixed Point Theorem ensures
existence and uniqueness.
Third step: continuity of the solution.
We have obtained existence and uniqueness of a solution U = (u, ut ) ∈ X ⊂

for any ρ′ and q ′ satisfying (6). This is a similar calculation to the first step.
Indeed,

≤ CT ε kU ; Lq (0, T ; Y ρ )kp + kU0 ; Y μ k < ∞.
In particular U ∈ L∞ (0, T, Y μ ). Now, using (9), for 0 ≤ t0 ≤ t, we have
kU (t) − U (t0 ); L∞ (t0 , t; Y μ ) ≤ kU (t) − H(t − t0 )U0 k + kU (t0 ) − H(t − t0 )U0 k.
As in the first step
kU (t) − H(t − t0 )U0 ; L∞ (t0 , t; Y μ )k ≤ C(t − t0 )ε kU (t); Lq (t0 , t; Y ρ )kp ,
and the strong continuity of the C0 -group H associated to the wave equation
implies that
lim kH(t − t0 )U0 − U0 ; L∞ (t0 , t; Y μ )k = 0.

Therefore, U ∈ C 0 ([0, T ]; Y μ ).
